reviewText:
Even though this game is over 4 years old it still holds up as being one of, if not THE best zombie game on the market. It's not only fun playing single player but it's hilarious when you can get three more friends to join in the zombie killing.

There's of course the standard Easy - Hard difficulities (Here being Easy, Medium, Advanced and Expert). So if you're looking for some mindless slaughtering to do you can put it on easy or if you and your friends is a tatical squad preparing for the zombie apacolypse this is a great way to start!

Also you don't have to play the first game to get into this one, all the maps and more from the first game is in this one. Even if you want to play oldschool there is a mode for that. Speaking of modes, there's Versus mode which is exactly what it sounds like, you control both the infected and the survivors in rounds. The one who ends the final map with the most points win. There is also a realism version of this mode which means the survivers can't see the green/orange/red glow around them as they used to.

There's also Survival which is aslo what it sounds like. Survive for X amount of time and you get bronze, silver or a gold medal depending on the requirments for the map you're playing.

Scavanger is the last major gamemode, here you play as survivor and infected and the objective is to fill a generator with gas. Who wins depends on which team's the fastest.

Then, finally, there's something called mutation. These are pretty much fun little mini modes. For example you have to try and survive an entire campaign on your own, you and all your teamates have katanas and can't get other weapons, you need to carry around a lawngnome to win etc.

reviewText:
Yes, this game is good. It's worth buying. Yes, even after almost 7 years after the release people still play it even despite the fact it didn't really receive any new content. Why? Well, let me explain.

Is it good because of graphics? Totally not. Even for early 2010's graphics weren't anything that impressive. It's still almost the same Source engine which powered Half-Life 2 and episodes. Yes, it was constantly updated but it didn't really progress. I mean we still have the same concept from early 90's: a game server hosts a map and up to 16 or 32 (or even 64 in some modifications) players can join and move around the map. You can reach certain points of the map and it will load another map. And that's all about it. But it's not open-world in any sense. It's something that reminds me of Doom and Quake games. In fact Source was partially based on Quake engine after all.

But don't think graphics are bad. No, they are pretty enjoyable. I just don't recall technological advancement being a major selling point for this game. The game can impress you sometimes. Some textures look really dated. But overall it's just there. The game graphics won't make you scream in excitement, nor it will disappoint you even in 2016. A lot of stuff is destructible. I saw hours spent on zombie animations: infected puke, beat eachother, walk around, die spectacularly if killed. It's nice to see actual damage done to their zombies' bodies: some severe dismemberment and burning. But some may say graphics are kinda old. (Please don't think I'm one of these guys who only cares about polygons and realism, I'm just getting started.)

So maybe the story is the main element here? Nope, you can complete the entire game without even learning anything about the characters or what's actually going on. You and 3 other people are given a selection of weaponry, medical supplies, some other stuff. You have a very simple goal: get to your destination or do something. Just get out of there alive.

So why anything from 10 to 20 thousand people are playing this game right now? Why so many people played it for two or three thousand hours? Because of gameplay.

Words cannot describe how many different situations there are. There are only 10 or so types of enemies, 3 basic types of main weapons, a few different secondary weapons, grenades and other items. And that's it. I know it may sound a lot at first but very quickly you acquire a taste for a favorite combination of weapons and items.

Left 4 Dead series somehow manage to make people spend thousands of hours of their time playing the same set of maps. And it's a corridor shooter which means there is only one way to achieve your destination. How it's done then? Well, every time different items get generated in different places, you get zombies from different spawn points. You can play the same maps over and over, again and again. And people actually do.

Speaking of people, it's a multiplayer. Yes, there is single-player mode where you can complete campaign with bots. But the most fun is playing with people. I find PvE aspect extremely interesting. Keep in mind your enjoyment really depends on people you play with. This game is about cooperation, you will never be able to complete it alone. So you have to find a server with good players, maybe you should play with friends, maybe you should make friends with people who play properly. Playing with bunch of griefers will suck. Playing with someone who actually wants to play is the best thing since sliced bread. Holy crap, you have to help eachother. Someone shares a medkit with you. His medkit. A medkit is being spent to restore your health you wasted because you made bunch of mistakes. But someone helps you for some reason. And you help them back, sharing resources with them. Oh, and keep in mind there is no reward system for helping others.

There is PvP where you play as a bunch of zombies against a team of survivors controlled by other players. But I don't think it's as good as regular campaign. If someone thinks you are bad for the team, they just kick you out. Call me a weirdo, but I play it because of sense of fellowship or at least some basic positive human interaction. I don't really like the idea that someone may feel bad because I outsmarted them.

I think I finally cracked Valve's logic. The main thing about a videogame is gameplay. This is exactly why we have these debates “%gamename% isn't a real videogame!!11” and other stuff. It's gameplay first. Yes, you need amazing visuals to make a masterpiece but it isn't the main thing you should focus on. I heard about Crysis as a game with great graphics many years ago, finally I decided to give it a try. I was utterly bored after a couple of hours — its gameplay was dull. Yes, you need story and great sound effects. But they still are only an excuse for gameplay.

Left 4 Dead 2 doesn't fail to illustrate this concept. You can play it right away, you don't have to read wiki for 2 hours to craft a pickaxe or to build a basic rocket to orbit Kerbin. It takes minutes to learn basic concepts. “Easy to learn, difficult to master” — yes, we have it. But after a couple of hours I began to care about the story. You play as one of 4 characters, who are they? Turns out they are almost real people with some depth to them. Not too much, just enough to understand how they feel about each other. The whole story of zombie virus is told through surroundings. You see countless writings on the walls, a lot of documents are scattered around. The story told not using some boring and forced cutscenes but using details. You may skip story elements if you don't care about it. Or you may spend hours reading L4D wiki like I did.

Valve remembers that this is a game. If you look through L4D concept art, you will see that survivors were supposed to look a lot more different. They wore a lot more utilitarian gear. In the final game they are wearing casual clothing which helps to establish who they were before the outbreak. I mean look at Rochelle's ear rings. I know what zombies would tear away first. It's unrealistic, and is it bad? Nope, it's fine, it's a videogame, not a reflection of reality.

There is a lot of stuff in Left 4 Dead series which have never been done before. Developers added commentaries in game how they ended up creating everything, it's really interesting to check out. And I think I finally understand Valve's logic: they create games with some new elements. They create a game, it succeeds. Then they make a sequel which feels much better, they implement everything they need to make a great videogame experience. This is exactly what happened to Portal and Portal 2, Left 4 Dead and Left 4 Dead 2. This is exactly why Half-Life 3 may never happen: what exactly new can you say about first person shooter genre? It was told so many times, it's really hard to come up with something new. And this is exactly why they keep working on Left 4 Dead 3. At least it seems they are working on it. After all Left 4 Dead 2 appears to be incomplete to me. I feel like you can add more stuff in this concept.

But right now it's totally worth spending money on Left 4 Dead 2. It's a very addictive game, and most importantly people are still playing it. If you get bored, there are tons of content in Steam Workshop you can b-a-s-t-a-r-d-ize the game with (if in you are in that kind of stuff).

reviewText:
I can't stress enough about how this game, right here, is argueably the best game you could ever get in the Steam store. Everything from the gameplay, co-op, mechanics, narrative, game modes, visuals, weapons, characters and the modding community are equally all fantastic and highly remarkable. It's one of those essential games every PC gamer must have in their Steam library. It's a massive step-up to the first game in the franchise and it would take a lot of hardwork and determination to make a sequel that could ever hope to topple this one.

I could write a much longer in-depth review about this brilliant game, but either you, the reader already acknowledge a lot about this game, through its strong magnitude and reputation. On the other hand, I personally would just want to leave it as the hidden gem, for the very small, minimal group of people who are still not familiar with this game, even to this day. With a message to those people, being simple and direct; you will not be disappointed by how much this game lives up to.

I would advice the newcomers to this game to take it slowly and definitely look out for the -75% off sales or even better, the free offer of this game which is most frequently appearing on big Steam sales. I hope this short and simple review will come in handy and have a happy halloween!

reviewText:
Energizing versus mode(s,) breath (and life)-taking COOP experience; a world of add-on maps available, easy to mod.  I'll let my six thousand hours speak for themselves!  This is just one of those games you can't beat unless a fantastic sequel is made for it.  Here's to hoping!  Nobody does it better than Valve.  You get your money's worth with their games.  This one is no exception.  Even if you purchase L4D2 on sale, or if it ends up part of some bundle, you're still coming out ahead.  I challenge any new player to this game, or skeptic for that matter, to play out the first full campaign (all maps,) and then re-evaluate if your're still uninterested/skeptical.

I'm confident you'll be happy you gave this game a chance;  some games are hyped and popular for a reason:  They're GREAT games!

They could have taken my money, but all they got away with was my heart.   I paid 3 times more for games that I could never play a fraction as much as this.  I'll refrain from promoting a modded community I serve in, but let me say, to sum it up:   there is An L4D2 Experience" for EVERYONE!

Buy it."

reviewText:
The successor to Left 4 Dead, this second game adds new maps, new weapons, new special infected with new attacks and even new characters. But in many ways the most important different between the two games is the scoring system.

Without mods, the first games scoring system really did tend to induce rage. A single mistake on a map and you could lose so many points that teams would be totally demoralized and either fall apart (making the game effectively over) or just quit (making it absolutely over). For hardcore players this was half the fun, but for the average casual player it could make Left 4 Dead a little too frustrating.

Left 4 Dead 2 on the other hand had a far more forgiving score system allowing teams who fail badly on map 1 to still feel they have a good chance of clawing the in back in the next 3 or 4 maps. With party wipes being a little less likely due to the removal of the quad cap, Left 4 Dead 2 is still a game people can play causally and still enjoy. With the extra variety of a lot more special infected meaning a lot more variety in possible tactics, Left 4 Dead 2 is still one of the best team focused games that I have ever played.

If you have a small group of close friends who love winning through superior team work rather than superior twitch skills, Left 4 Dead 2 is one of the best PvP games you could try. But be warned, playing with random people you have never met can be rewarding, but more often than not it can be bloody annoying.

HOURS ON RECORD : I don't play this game on my public account. I have over 1500 my private account.

reviewText: L4D2 is a vast improvement in L4D in almost every respect. It actually has a plot for starters. Each chapter flows into the next as the four main characters try to escape hordes of the infected. That's right! They're not actually zombies folks! They're just humans infected by a virus that makes them exhibit zombie like personality traits, a plot line also been used a million times. But the plot is really not what matters here, it's not supposed to be important, as much as the plot as I got from the game without trying to find it was Here are some zombies
recommended: have fun." What we're really here for is the gameplay.\n\nIn addition to your weapons you can hold presents such as Molotov's or Pipe Bomb's
hoursPlayed: the latter of which is incredibly useful and incredibly awesome to behold. If you don't enjoy hundreds of zombies piling together then have their exploded body parts ragdoll through the air then something clearly went wrong when God was handing out the human brains and bird brains.\n\nAlong with your dopey common infected are the more dangerous and lethal special infected who can ravage through a player's health in a matter of seconds as well as separate them from the group. These zombies must be brought down together and the players must constantly stay together to rescue each other from these zombies unless they want to lie down seductively on a dinner plate instead. The strongest of these are the Witch and the Tank

reviewText:
I have been playing Left 4 Dead since the original came out on Xbox 360 in 2008. Once I got a PC that could run Left 4 Dead 2, I discovered that Left 4 Dead really has no end of enjoyment. It is not for everyone of course, but if you like slaying zombies, exploration, teamwork, fun with friends, and some hilarious moments, this game is excellent.

It is now 2016, and still, people are making mods, addons, skins, new game modes, and creating unique servers that change the rules of the game. It is hard to get bored with a game that people keep adding to this much.

You will unfortunately hear about, or experience yourself, bad players on this game. This goes for EVERY game out there on the Internet. If there is a way to ruin other players' fun, there are people who will try to do it. Please don't blame the game for bad players. Left 4 Dead 2 still has hundreds, maybe thousands of players who love to have a good time and try to support eachother in game. I'm one of those. =D If you have a bad experience, try again please. More good-natured players are always welcome.

To me, this is the best game in the world right now. This is because it provides a fun way to meet cool and amazing people, who enjoy this great game where you are rewarded for working TOGETHER, instead of just killing eachother. The game itself provides lots of fun, but what really makes it amazing are the people you play with, and people who continue to make the game better.

I have put off writing a review to this game for so long, because I really can't say enough about it. This review seems like it barely scratches the surface to me. All I can say is try it. TRY IT. Join some games, download some add ons and try those. Remember not to take it too seriously. Get killed, laugh, try to get better, die more, laugh even more. XD Left 4 Dead forever haha.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead 2 is a first-person shooter game from Valve. It is a sequel to the previous game Left 4 Dead.

Left 4 Dead 2 lets you play as another group of four survivors on a brand new campaign with a crossover campaign from the first game too. These new survivors are Rochelle, Coach, Ellis and Nick. This sequel has more game modes to play and even more choice of weapons to use against the undead, but there are also new types of special infected too, so be prepared to be amazed, or dead. It seems that Valve finally decided to add Left 4 Dead campaign into this new game, but the feels are different as the new infected also present in the old campaign along with the new weapons and improved graphics, making the game even more replayable.

Left 4 Dead 2 also comes with Steam Workshop support so there are lots of user made custom content you can download to customize your game, like custom weapons, custom survivors, custom infected and special infected, custom maps and event some people made custom campaign with their own story. You can also make your own content and share it with public.

Overall, Left 4 Dead 2 is a really good sequel. I recommend this.

Rating 9/10

33/11 would kill teammate for boat again.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead 2 is a very fun adventure game in which you team up with 3 others and kill countless zombies as you fight for your survival. Utilise many weapons such as assault rifles, pistols, axes and even chainsaws. It has a good storyline as well, making the characters who need to survive quite interesting as they have to interact with eachother. While the zombie-killing is fun, after a while it will get reptitive and you'll run out of fun ways to kill zombies. Another downside is that you should really play it with others, as with bots it is really bad because they act like they have no brain. There are a good range of modes however, even ones when you get to control zombies!

Pros:
+Good variety of weapons and fun ways to kill zombies
+Good story
+Fun with 4 people
+Good modes

Cons:
-Can get repetitive, depending on how you view it
-Bad if you're on your own

Verdict:
9.1/10.0

reviewText:
Ruined my gaming life and at the same time it really enhanced it. I met most people on my friends list on it and became really good friends with some of them.

I'm mostly a Scavenge and Survival player. Yeah, I don't really like Versus and Campaign, which are the most played game modes. Being a Scavenge player, where the community is way smaller, I get to know basically everyone who plays it regularly and when I join a game (mostly on the Rooftop map) it's guaranteed that I will meet someone there who is either on my friends list or that I knew before just by playing. I'd say the best years to play this game mode where 2010-2013, it just died from there on to nowadays, but surprisingly, there's people who still play Scavenge, so there's always at least 1 game.

Left 4 Dead 2's main problem, unlike most FPS games, isn't hackers. It's the community itself, specially the tryhards. Those morons that take video gaming more seriously than real life (well, they probably don't have a proper life to begin with anyway). Yeah, they get mad in public matches if people don't have over 2.000 hours and don't skeet every Hunter they see, even if their team is winning. You're going to have a hard time playing the PvP gamemodes, Scavenge and Versus, if you don't have at least 200 or 300 hours on Campaign and Survival you're going to be judged (if your profile isn't set to private or friends-only).

Don't expect a horror shooting game, there's no horror elements in Left 4 Dead 2. The creepiest thing (if you can call it that) is the Witch, and even so, she's kinda... cute. Expect an action game with a toxic PvP community and a (mostly) friendly PvE one.

reviewText:
I couldnt decide what to write in this review , so im gonna share with you guys my favorite apple pie recipe Enjoy! :

Pastry

2  cups  all-purpose flour

1  teaspoon salt

2/3 cup plus 2 tablespoons shortening

4 to 6 tablespoons cold water

Filling

1/3   to 1/2 cup sugar

1/4 cup  all-purpose flour

1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon

1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg

1/8  teaspoon salt

8 cups thinly sliced peeled tart apples (8 medium)

2  tablespoons butter or margarine

1) In medium bowl, mix 2 cups flour and 1 teaspoon salt. Cut in shortening, using pastry blender (or pulling 2 table knives through ingredients in opposite directions), until particles are size of small peas. Sprinkle with cold water, 1 tablespoon at a time, tossing with fork until all flour is moistened and pastry almost cleans side of bowl (1 to 2 teaspoons more water can be added if necessary).

2) Gather pastry into a ball. Divide in half; shape into 2 flattened rounds on lightly floured surface. Wrap in plastic wrap; refrigerate about 45 minutes or until dough is firm and cold, yet pliable. This allows the shortening to become slightly firm, which helps make the baked pastry more flaky. If refrigerated longer, let pastry soften slightly before rolling.

3) Heat oven to 425°F. With floured rolling pin, roll one pastry round into round 2 inches larger than upside-down 9-inch glass pie plate. Fold pastry into fourths; place in pie plate. Unfold and ease into plate, pressing firmly against bottom and side.

4) In large bowl, mix sugar, 1/4 cup flour, the cinnamon, nutmeg and 1/8 teaspoon salt. Stir in apples until well mixed. Spoon into pastry-lined pie plate. Cut butter into small pieces; sprinkle over filling. Trim overhanging edge of pastry 1/2 inch from rim of plate.

5)  Roll other round of pastry into 10-inch round. Fold into fourths and cut slits so steam can escape. Unfold top pastry over filling; trim overhanging edge 1 inch from rim of plate. Fold and roll top edge under lower edge, pressing on rim to seal; flute as desired. Cover edge with 2- to 3-inch strip of foil to prevent excessive browning.

6)  Bake 40 to 50 minutes or until crust is brown and juice begins to bubble through slits in crust, removing foil for last 15 minutes of baking. Serve warm if desired.

reviewText:
Over 2000 hours and I still haven't reviewed this game! well here goes...

Do you like zombies? Do you like guns? Do you like Mariocart? Do you like to spam right-click like your middle finger has Parkinsons? Well you are going to love this!

L4D2 is a unique, fast paced twitch shooter with loads of replayability. Even if you get bored of the official valve content there are tons of fun community maps to try out. In particular I recommend Questionable Ethics and The Bloody Moors. Despite the zombie theme L4D2 is not really a horror game and the L4D2 campaign and characters in particular are pretty cartoonish compared to the darker design of the original Left 4 Dead. However, all of the L4D1 maps were ported over to L4D2 a long time ago now, so there isn't much need to buy the original unless you are really curious or nostalgic about it.

The game is getting a bit old now with alot less people online than there used to be. Consequently mosty of the players you find online are either veterans/long term addicts of the game or newbies from the previous sale. This only really applies to the PvP modes of the game (Versus and Scavenge) but new players are going to have a tough time in public games because of this. L4D2 does not have a very high skill ceiling like Counter Strike or Quake but there is still a fairly steep learning curve to start with. In any random public game you are likely to be playing with players who have 1000+ hours who know the maps like the back of their hand and know all the various little tricks and strats. You will find them frustrating to play against and they will find it frustrating having you on their team. This is the kind of game where one player can really drag a whole team down so if you are that player you can expect to be kicked alot. If you are new you should start out playing versus with friends, or get onto some 10v10 commuinity servers where you can mess around without getting kicked from the game.

People say that the public versus community is really terrible but I dont think it is any worse than other PvP games apart from the fact that some of the game mechanics specific to L4D2 make people rage such as the forced dependence on teammates and some of the inherent randomness of the game. In fact I would say that the versus community is better now that it was 4 years ago when the game was more popular. For example most of the time now people will 'ready up' before starting a round, whereas before it was normal to see people deliberately rushing out of spawn while players are still loading in. But yeah... if you are new you are going to need thick skin in public versus.

Versus is definately the most replayable mode, and the reason why many people keep playing this game for thousands of hours, but it what I said above puts you off you can always stick to playing the co-operative modes which are slower paced and with more easygoing players. The exception to this is expert difficulty, where friendly fire damage is signifigant and effects playstyle alot. Because of friendly fire expert is also the biggest target for griefers. Playing alot of expert co-op will make you paranoid about teamkillers and you will start to accumulate a nice big blocklist.

Anyway what I have written might come across as negative but I think it is honest view based on over 2000 hours of gameplay which by itself says alot about addictive and replayable this game is. I don't think I have ever played any other game for as many hours, and no other game has made me laugh or rage as much as L4D2.

reviewText:
If I said L4D2 isn't a good game, I would be lying. Besides, what is my review compared to the fact that it has been one of the top-rated games of its era?

Remember those horror movies involving zombies where the main characters run and hide when chased? Left 4 Dead 2 is nothing like that.

In Left 4 Dead 2, when you see zombies, you run towards them.

You shoot them, you cut them, you slice them, you dice them, you saw them apart, you burn them. Basically do anything to kick their undead asses so hard they'd wish they stayed in hell.

And then they send the big guns against you. The special kinds that have special abilities to horrify you.

And then you rinse and repeat. You blow them to smithereens, you smack them to kingdom come, you tenderize them.

And when you can stand there in a group of 4, and the dead actually fears you, you'll know this is a game that screams:

Come at me

reviewText: A lot can be said about this game, but there's something specific I want to say about this game after seeing the popularity of recent multiplayer games like Evolve and Payday 2.\n\nLeft 4 Dead 2 is a great example of replayability done right. It doesn't try to keep you playing with progression, but with sheer FUN. While a lot of online games these days will beat you over the head with an experience bar and taunt you with unlockables, Left 4 Dead 2 doesn't keep anything from you, and from the word go, you have access to whatever equipment you find randomly strewn across its maps. It focuses on making any given campaign run or round of versus unique and interesting, and you as a player get to enjoy the journey instead of simply anticipating the destination. This isn't a game where you grab the SMG because you want some kind of SMG bonus afterward, or you sneak past a sobbing zombie woman so you can get an experience bonus the next time you play. This is a game where you grab a shotgun because you want to shoot that Witch in her stupid, crying face.

reviewText:
This is a really nice game - together or alone.
Because even if you're just one player, there will be 3 mates with you, wich are also necessary, because this badass Zombies are in great MAJORITY.
There are a lot of different types of Zombies, and some of them can only be defeated by teamwork. Some of the Levels are designed slightly creepy and all of them are having a different type of theme. A roller coaster, or the swamp, a storm at night? Everything's possible.
But what's woth to buy this game, when you can't kill those guys? Well - you can! And to do so you can find a bunch of different weapons all over the maps. An Axe, Machete, Katana, and - of course - guns. A lot of guns.
The story isn't anything really new, but for zombie-games there isn't much space to experiment with that. But it's not bad in any way.

Final words: This game is much fun to play with friends, or all alone with the help of the your fellows. With a lot of different modes you can spend a lot of time in this great game and it's definitely worth it.

reviewText: Left 2 Die is a military shooter developed by Bethesda Game Studios and published by Electronic Arts. It's focused around a group of five highly-trained military professionals and is known for its high degree of realism and gritty, immersive plot.\nUnfortunately, the game falls short of excellence for several reasons. First, the game does not let you use iron sights on any of the weapons. This detracts greatly from the realism of the game and makes complex tactics like run-and-gun completely unviable. Second, there are no custom classes or leveling system. The lack of a ranking system, or Prestige
date: means that there is no sense of fulfillment in the game. You cannot paint your weapons different colors to make them distinct and realistic, nor can you unlock stronger weapons, forcing you to rely purely on luck, and spending hours upon hours scavenging for supplies and usable equipment is a complete chore. Additionally, the game lacks prone and sprint mechanics. This is very unrealistic because you cannot lie on the ground and you cannot go fast enough for to the game.\nAside from the five original soldiers, the game allows you to play as eight different SI's
recommended: or Secret Infiltrators. The SI fill varying roles, from support to close-quarters combat, to intelligence-gathering. Unfortunately, the game discourages teamwork, leaving players with almost no tactical options. Additionally, the Infiltrators cannot use firearms, which detracts from the realism of the game. This is surprising, considering that the developers at Treyarch have a long history of creating tactical masterpieces.\nThe levels are poorly designed, with no objective other than to make it from one Staging Room to the next, with a lengthy extraction stage at the end of every operation. These frantic levels are just confusing, making the game very hostile towards newcomers. It is disappointing that Square Enix decided to develop a tactical modern military shooter with no objective other than survival.\nIn spite of the game's numerous flaws, the devs at Rovio have truly outdone themselves in creating a modern masterpiece of storytelling. The narrative in Left 2 Die, the newest game from renown developer Naughty Dog, is involving and profoundly emotional, moreso than their earlier titles such as LittleBigPlanet" and "The First of Them." The five soldiers all have very distinct personalities
hoursPlayed: and the backstory is rich and enchanting. The ending is nothing short of sublime; without spoiling anything
voteText: Irrational Games has managed to surpass the storytelling sucess seen in their earlier title
helpfulPercent: "System Shock."\nLeft 2 Die follows an episodic format
votesHelpful: allowing players to purchase each episode seperately or buy a "Season Card" to make every episode available the minute they are completed by Rockstar Games. Each episode is roughly 30 minutes long and ends in a stunning cliffhanger that blends in seamlessly with the next episode. This innovative DLC format is sure to pave the way for games to come
votesTotal: and at $40 per episode
votesFunny: is worth every penny.\nThe Creative Assembly has truly outdone themselves in their latest game
commentsCount: Left 2 Die. The title is sure to satisfy all types of gamers
column16: from the casual to the hardcore
column18: I rate the latest DOTA 2 expansion pack
column21: unforgettable.\n\nEDIT: Also something about the community being a literal cesspit"

reviewText:
Let me start with this: I love the L4D series; both games. The gameplay and various stories really tops it off.

That's the sad part.

Unless you decide that you want to play solo or maybe with some friends, don't bother with this game. It's really nice, and I mean REALLY nice to play offline, but any attempt to play online will be immediately refuted by the majority of players who happen to be super pro elitist ***holes. You will get kicked for everything, and I mean EVERYTHING. I've been kicked for opening a door, healing a partner, accidentally incapacitating a partner who was at 1 health and in the middle of the crossfire, using a med kit because I'm low on health, being pinned by a zombie, AND MY FAVORITE, being a f***king new guy. You CANNOT play multiplayer as a new guy because the elitists forget that you have to practice to get good. Seriously. The Community is by far the worst in current gaming history. Avoid them if at all possible.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game and is one of my favorite games of all time, so I'm giving this a positive review.

That being said, I'll have to address the matter of this game that completely destroys it. A simple word, 'Community'. Out of all of the communities of games, movies, etc, this is the worst one I have ever came across. This community is full of elitists, ridden with them. They always kick you for doing the slightest thing wrong or not doing what they want you to do.
For example;

About to die and stops to heal = kick.
Killing a zombie that someone else was about to kill = kick.
Just missing a player as a charger = kick.
Walks out of spawn and immediately gets pounced = kick.

So why do I recommend this game you ask? It's because of the game itself. I only play this game with friends (for obvious reasons) and that is a highly fun experience. If you are planning on going on a pub server, bring around two other people with you, therefore you have less chances of getting kicked.

reviewText:
I can honestly say that Left 4 Dead 2 would be my favourite zombie multiplayer game right now. It's a sequel to Left 4 dead. Same concept but more features added. It adds newer maps, different characters, more playable special infecteds, and a bunch load of more weapons to slaughter zombies with. You basically travel through different areas with your teammates trying to find an escape route. What more can you say about it? It's a fun coop game where you can play with your friends or any other online players from across the world.

Besides from just going to different saferooms and finding an escape vehicle on a finale campaign on the same maps, there are other gamemodes you can play to eliminate the boredom. Survival is a great and challenging gamemode where your teammates and you have to try to survive on a map for as long as you can with the resources that will be provided around the map. Great mode for strategy and setting a goal for surviving for maybe longer than 10 minutes or even an hour. The longer the time, the more crucial it'll get. Versus is another gamemode you can also try out. Probably is the most popular and playful gamemode in the game. It's a fun and competitive game which consist of two teams. One as special infecteds and one who plays as the survivors. After completing a map, both teams will rotate positions depending on who won last round. The team with the most points after completing the finale will be declared as the winner. This I believe is the only gamemode where you actually have the ability to play as a special infected which is a fun feature in the game.

With some of the updates that Left 4 Dead 2 offered us, you can actually have the ability to play as the old characters and the old maps from the first Left 4 dead. This means that there are more maps for you to try out and more characters for you to select. You don't even need to purchase the first Left 4 Dead. Also adds two extra maps for you to play on such as The Sacrafice" played by the Left 4 Dead characters and "Cold Stream" played by the Left 4 Dead 2 Characters.

If you get bored of just playing normal vanilla games
date: you can try out some of the special steam group servers. These servers are made by other people where they can provide special features in the game that originally aren't in the game. They bring out a new level of fun and diversity. A fort spawner server for Survival where you can build a fort/shelter to help you fight away the zombies. An RPG leveling system server for Campaign and Versus where you can level up your character and acquire unique  perks and abilities to make you much stronger to slay the infected.\n\nI met most of cool online friends on this game. It has been here for a while now and is still a popular game to this day. I would extremely recommend getting this game if you're into horror
recommended: fun or just love smashing zombies with a frying pan. It's only $21.99
hoursPlayed: which is fairly a cheap price for a great game."

reviewText:
One of my favourite games ever. 9/10.

Great multi-player co-op game that still has a ton of replay value, six years later. Where it really shines is in Versus mode, where teams play against each other, taking turns playing as the Special Infected.  Left 4 Dead 2 is simply a must-have for all survival horror enthusiasts. The new game modes and the usual mix of adrenaline and co-op gameplay is the living(dead) proof that a sequel doesn’t always have to change its original nature to be enjoyable, very enjoyable!

Before playing Versus mode, however, make sure you have played through Campaign mode completely at least once.

Of course, story is for single player games, and L4D2 certainly isn't that. To get the most out of the game, you need to play it with three other people, especially on higher difficulties where the AI companions are all but useless. They'll do a good enough job at shooting zombies, but often get sidetracked at killing a few straggling common infected, while your busy fighting a Tank. Or, they'll continually shout We need to stick together!" when you try and keep moving
date: but they just won't follow you. The most frustrating is during the game's gauntlet events
recommended: where you have to go and turn off something like an alarm

reviewText:
Are you looking for some zombie-survival fun with your friends? (Not looking at you, Walking Dead. Your game is boring!) Wait no more! This is what you and your friends are looking for.

Play Campaign Mode, where you and your friends must pass through many areas from a map, full of hordes to shoot in their faces, and escape from the map. Just like a badäss!

Play Survival Mode, where you and your friends must survive as many time as possible. Making you a time-attacking badäss!

Play Mutation Mode, where you have many different ways to play and you must prove Chuck Norris how a mighty badäss you are in many ways!

Play Versus Mode or Scavenge Mode, where in both modes you can be in the human team or in the zombie team, regardless of which team you are, your victory makes you more badäss!

Don't miss the chance! If you miss it, we're going after you! Bring your friends, bring your colleagues, bring your mother, that's right, your mother!

reviewText:
In this game you will be introduced with a high-school football “Coach” but with a bad knee, a cold and sarcastic gambler and con artist Nick, Rochelle who is a low level production assistant and reporting on the evacuation for local TV station and a friendly mechanic Ellis.

As a start, the four survivors found themselves at an abandoned hotel roof by the rescue chopper. This is the start of Dead Center. So, they decided to reach the local mall where a second CEDA evacuation point is located. By their way after finishing correspondence with gun shop owner Whitaker, they discovered that the mall is overrun by infected. At such a situation Ellis helped the group to use a stock car and to travel towards New Orleans, probably the last standing city of America.

The Passing stands in between Dead Center and Dark Carnival just after The Sacrifice. The four of the L4D2 survivors when arrive at the bridge of Rayford they meet Francis, Louis and Zoey. Since they need to cross the bridge so they four found the other way. After fighting their way through a wedding reception of witch bride, the streets and under the river tour they meet up again with the original survivors who provided covering fire while filling up the generator or lowering the bridge.

Dark Carnival starts in a highway completely blocked by ditched vehicles. Starting from there survivors reached at an abandoned amusement park. At the park stadium Coach found a plan to use a large scale light show used by The Midnight Riders to signal the rescue chopper.

Yet bad luck… they found the chopper pilot is infected! Naturally, Nick killed him and it crashed so also Swamp Fever starts. So, crossing the swamps the group finally arrives at plantation mansion and makes radio contact with Virgil, a boat captain. But his boat starts to run low on diesel on the way to New Orleans. Hard rain starts, the survivors go to shore at Ducatel. Crossing a witch infested sugarcane mill finally they get gas from gas station and return back with fuels to signal Virgil.

Virgil drops the group at New Orleans where military is evacuating civilians across a bridge. But the four discovered that the city is completely overrun by infected and so the military is actually leaving the city before it is destroyed by air strike. However, survivors managed to reach the bridge and made contact with the military. Then crossing the bridge they were evacuated by chopper and the bridge was destroyed with the end of The Parish.

All the best so far but the day is important because we have night!!! :) I don’t mean this for zombie apocalypse though!! :) So, foxed? :-D Well, you may encounter various types of trolls (special infecteds? :d), ... ... etc. etc. in the community when you will want multiplayer but just don’t let them feel you down ever to enjoy the thrills of the game because I assure you they are never more than a few. :)

So, don’t you want to experience all these in more details playing the game by your own? I wanted all these learnings and hope you too. :)

reviewText:
I'm having a blast playing this game. I can't believe I've had it so long in my library and never touched it.

Pros:
Very, very challenging.
A lot of replay value.
Team work is needed, communication is key.
Very tactful / tactical. If you think you're going to run around in this game blasting zombies, you're in for a big surprise. Check all your corners and watch your six!
The AI is not too terrible and can hold its own on Expert.
Many game modes to choose from.
The Expert mode does not bend over for casuals like some other games in the same genre.
A healthy player base even after 7 years.
Cons:
Team Killing. There are a lot of trolls in this game that will join your game and TK you. I've experienced at least one per gaming session. This can be very frustrating if trying to do a map on Expert. It'd be nice if there was a Ricochet option (whatever damage you deal to teammates is done back to you instead) that was on by default.
Toxic community. Playing on VS is a sure-fire way to get insults hurled your way -- even if you go through the entire campaign on expert. They don't tolerate beginners at VS even though they were beginners once.
For maps that have require gathering scattered items during the middle of a Panic event, the AI is useless, making these events virtually impossible on Solo.
The AI will stay back and fight rather than follow you and kite. This is mainly important when dealing with a Tank.
Weapons feel rather bland, but they'll grow on you eventually.
If you cancel a reload on Expert, you'll have to play out the entire reload animation all over again and your magazine count will be at 0 even if you had at least 1 bullet in it before.

reviewText:
Want to play with friends and survive in a zombie apocalypse?  Then L4D2 is a game for you!

I always had fun with a friend when playing online and it's easy to create your own lobby. Noteworthy, the more friends playing, the better.

Having the  Director avaliable to change the gameplay everytime you play also helps to make sure the game doesn't becoming too boring. You can also crank up the difficulty for a challenge (be warned though that if you're playing in expert mode, bring 3 other friends)!

One issue I had with this game were the origin of the weapons (in other words, the way the weapons were held). The original game was fine but now, they're too centered in the screen and/or take up too much space (like the hunting rifle). However, this issue can be fixed" in the workshop by downloading custom content and there's even an add-on that re-origins the default weapons. If you cannot find something in the workshop that you want/like
date: don't worry as it's very easy to install custom add-ons (from other websites) through the L4D2 file directories.\n\nThere is another problem I keep facing when playing online in public lobbies. Some players should have practiced more and adjusted to the game by playing offline but instead

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead gave me my start in online gaming.  My noobiness was easily forgiven by the zombies, however, if you play with other players, be prepared to hear a little bit of criticism, especially if you do versus.  Overall, I really enjoy this game and I am quite pleased that Valve incorporated the first Left 4 Dead maps into it.

However, the original maps are starting to get a little old despite the recently added Cold Stream, but, having said that, this is still one of my most favorite games.  So, if you are looking for a good game to play with other people and have a few drinks, Left 4 Dead can offer you a good time!

Still hoping for a third installment! L4D3! L4D3! L4D3!! :D

reviewText:
The best cooperative game in the world, without a doubt.

I don't know how to explain it- with this gaming series Valve created their own genre. It looks old and cliched, with the zombies, promises of teamwork and lots of guns, but ignore that: it's a surprisingly refreshing concept done in such an original way that there is nothing to compare it to. It was well received but I still think that this game was underrated. Left 4 Dead 3, if it ever comes out, will tip the world on its head. Best start preparing for it now with L4D2!

The game DEMANDS teamwork, and actively encourages it. There is nothing to gain from running on ahead and leaving others behind, you're all in this zombie apocalypse together. It's amazing how you can join a server with 3 random people and within the space of a couple of hours, get to know each of them well enough that you want to add them all to your friends list.

Much like GTA 5 or the Sims, this game has universal appeal. Yup, girls enjoy it too. I'm not going to say anything since I'll likely unintentionally come across as sexist, but I'll simply say that it's a testament to this game that everybody can enjoy it. I reckon that my parents would too if they would see past the gore.

It may look as though it's you versus zombies, but you're really up against 'The Director'. It is a mysterious, invisible force who decides where to leave weapons and items lying around in the level. If you're doing too well, it'll chuck a crowd of zombies at you. 'The Director' shapes the pacing and feeling of the game and makes each play-through different to the last. It adds enormous replayability to a game that's already bursting with features and game modes.

Oh yes, this game includes everything from the first game (rendering it completely obsolete), as well as 4 new characters with their own campaign spanning several separate worlds. You now have melee weapons, chainsaws, grenade launchers, vials-of-sick and deagles to aid you in your struggle against the undead. And The Director.

But don't worry- the zombies have some new tricks up their saggy-skin sleeves as well. You have 6 special infected who are a match for lone humans, as well as sitting and walking witches and the almighty tank. You have armoured zombies who can only be shot from the rear, mudmen who scuttle quickly below your vision and smear your view and industrial workers with shiny jackets that make them sitting ducks. Idiots.

You'll begin to fear the groan of the zombies. You'll get goosebumps at the sound of the musical cues. You'll love the sight of the saferoom and get a warm fuzzy feeling from using your medikit to heal a team member. This game has been a staple of my weekend nights for years and I'm still not tired of it. It's the perfect LAN game and as if the game wasn't good enough already, it also has a versus mode where you take in turns to be the special zombies and must stop the humans from achieving what ever it is those foolish creatures do when the world ends. I haven't played this mode nearly as much as I'd have liked and the idea of it still gets me excited all of these years later.

In terms of fun / exciting / scary / frustrating things that you can squeeze into an hour of gameplay, Left 4 Dead wins hands down. The only down-side? The community isn't what it used to be. It's a real shame when you look at the server list and find so few people still playing. Expert mode is nigh on impossible to complete without some old hardcore friends joining to lend you a hand. You can forget expert realism!

Even without real people, you can still play the campaigns against bots. The game is still worth it for that alone, though of course it is better with other real people. Do yourself a favour if you haven't already and give this game a go. There really isn't anything as polished or as well designed as this game and Valve must be very proud of themselves for making it first.

reviewText:
More than 4 years after its release, this is still one of the very best (if not the best) co-operative FPS shooter, where teamwork is highly emphasized but you are also given complete freedom at doing whatever you want, although if you want to succeed easily in the missions, you will learn to enjoy and appreciate constant communication with your teammates.

The concept of the game has been clearly very well thought-out and over 400 hours later, i am still drawn to play this game and it never gets old. The campaign missions are great to familiarize yourself with the maps, the settings, the gameplay, the different infected and their distinctive attacks. Everything balances itself out at every turn. But the real strength of this game is its multiplayer. You simply cannot experience the full force of Left 4 Dead, without having played its many multiplayer modes. There are so many different game possibilities and different objectives. It is one of the very few games that can keep me going for several hours, irrespective if i'm tired or sleepy - the adrenaline rush just keeps me awake and the feeling of satisfaction if you work well as a team is simply tremendous.

There are also private game servers which offer even more customizable game modes. The standard versus mode for the official game is 4 vs 4. But on third-party servers, you will encounter 10 vs 10, which changes the game by enabling more chaos and way more fun. I highly recommend that you try it if you ever get tired of the official game modes and want to try something new and even more exciting.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead 2 is a cooperative first-person shooter and the sequel to Left 4 Dead.
The sequel picks up one week after the events of the first game where The Infection has spread to the southern United States.
Left 4 Dead 2 introduces new weapons, melee weapons and new items.
There is a new cast of human Survivors, which include: Coach, a portly high-school football coach with a bad knee; Nick, a rude and cynical gambler and con artist;Rochelle, a low-level production assistant reporting on the evacuation for a local television station; and Ellis, a friendly mechanic.
The game also introduces three new Special Infected: The Charger, The Spitter and The Jockey.
Left 4 Dead 2 currently has thirteen campaigns playable in all gameplay modes, six of which are from the original Left 4 Dead.
The game has 4 different game modes: Campaign, Versus, Survival and Scavenge.
During Campaign, also known as Co-op, up to four players work together to try to reach the end of the campaign by fighting their way past large numbers of AI-controlled Infected. There are four difficulty levels: Easy, Normal, Advanced and Expert.
Versus is the basic competitive mode for the Left 4 Dead series: two separate teams of four players take turns playing as the Survivors and the Infected competing for the most points.
The point of Survival Mode is to hold out for the longest time, with times being saved and virtual medals being awarded for surviving for certain amounts of time.
Scavenge is a competitive gameplay mode in Left 4 Dead 2. It is a round based game in which Survivors have a limited amount of time to find up to 21 gas cans to fuel up a generator (or car), while fighting against player-controlled Special Infected much like in a Versus game.
As in the first game, each scenario is presented like a movie. At the start of the game there is a movie poster showing the cast. At the end the credits" display the statistics for the game
date: like who killed the most zombies
recommended: who inflicted the most headshots and so on. The final credit shows how many zombies were killed in the making of the film and also the film is dedicated to the memory of those survivors who did not make it to safety.\nEvery aspect of Left 4 Dead has been refined and tweaked to perfection. It has brilliant graphics and a nice cinematic feel.\nThe new campaigns and unique game modes offer more variety and more longevity

reviewText:
Alright, I think I'm finally due for a review...
Back in 2008, Left 4 Dead caught my eye.  The idea of zombies, (How original, amirite, although It was a bit newer back then.) slicing their heads off, blowing off their legs with pipe bombs, and listening to them die to fire sounded freaking AWESOME.  So I pre-ordered it.  (I was a console peasant back then)
Let's just say it ruined my life in a very, very bad *ahem* good way..

By the time Left 4 Dead 2 was announced in 2009, I had already skipped school so many times continuing was probably pointless.  I hadn't seen my family more than for dinners in months and oh god was it so good. (I'm regretting it now, don't worry.)  So I pre-ordered it again.  (PEASANT.  ;_;)
Well yet again I lost my life.  Left 4 Dead probably was the cause of me dropping out of school twice.  And you know, the xbox community (this is back when there were people actually playing) actually wasn't half bad, or so I thought.

BOOM.  I have a computer.  Got both the games.  Didn't play 1 much, as I've already played way too much of it.  Left 4 dead 2 Scavenge mode was my absolute favorite on xbox, and now on PC even more so.  Versus I didn't want to get into, as in Left 4 Dead 1 I played way too much of it and got burnt out.  I learned so many new things and tricks that you just couldn't possibly do on a controller.  I met new friends, and with the lovely (xx hours in the last 2 weeks) tracker, I stopped playing so frickin' much.  (okay, sometimes.) The community here, even if it is filled with a bunch of cocky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, is obviously, better.

I definitely recommend this game.   If you're looking for a good zombie game to play, this one is great.  It's so simple, yet there is always room for improvement.  I doubt many people don't own it these days, as its always on frickin' sell.  If you don't have it, buy it already.

Just a few tips:
Learn the infected classes.  Like how the hunter needs to crouch before he can pounce in some way or another (more complicated moves are saved for later), and other stuff having to do with the infected.
This game is team based.  Your teammates matter.  If your teammates are struggling, help them, unless you are absolutely better off going alone (I can only think of a few scenarios).  If your teammates can't cover you and you're 'MLG PRO B@$$' don't be all 'g3t on my l3v37 n00b', switch freaking places with them.  That's your only hope.  You don't go solo here.
Same with infected.  Don't go solo.  Unless you're amazing and its a death charge, just don't.  You time your attacks accordingly, and work together to achieve the best results.
Remember, all of the best teams you will ever run into in Left 4 Dead 2 certaintly know that working together is essential.  They just do it better than us.
Use a mic + headphones / headset at all times.  Most people will get very annoyed if they can hear your game through your microphone, and let me tell you, trying to play a team based game with a mute person is not fun.
SHOOT ALL THE THINGS.
Gameplay Modes:
Campaign
Start by playing Campaign, either Solo or with friends.  Learn the controls up and down, & attempt to get the general rhythm of playing as a Survivor.
You can either play campaign solo with single player and computer controlled teammates, or you can play Co Op.  I strongly preferred Co Op, as single player can be boring.  It is much funner to play while you joke about with your friends.  We have a few difficulties, start from Easy and work your way up.  Or, screw it all and play expert for the lulz!  I know I did that a few times with some friends, and it was hilarious.

Survival
Play Survival for fun sometimes, its frustrating as you WILL die, but play it with your friends, and it will help you learn how to play as a team.
This gamemode is generally you and three other survivors duking it out on the map of your choice, against an endless horde of zombies and special infected.  The special infected are computer controlled.

You can play this alone or with teammates, but it's pointless without teammates.  This gamemode is great not only for trying to achieve an amazing time and the pure fun of that (and rage), but also because it will help improve your team working skills.  This is important.

Versus
When you feel like you understand the Infected classes and you feel comfortable playing as a team.
In this game mode two teams of four go head to head.  One starts as Survivor, one as Infected.  The general goal as an infected is to kill the other team as fast as you can while working together, or if you are on the Survivor side, to make it to the end with all of your teammates alive.  Each time a section of a map ends, you replay that map as the other class.  Whichever team has the most points at the end wins.

If you can, get a few friends together for a large versus game, where you won't run into a bunch of cocky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who don't remember they were new once too.  Otherwise, ♥♥♥♥ em' and just try to hold your own in a versus game.  You may get kicked, but don't let it get you down.  It's okay to make mistakes, that's how we learn, that is how we all learned.  Some people just forget that little fact.

Scavenge
When you feel like you understand the Infected classes and you feel comfortable playing as a team.
This game mode is like versus.  Except you play on one map, and one map only, for a number of rounds.  The point as the Survivors is to fill the generator on the map with gas cans, and the gas cans will be spread out across the map (easily visible, so no worries there).  On the other hand, the infected are trying to stop you.  They want you to either not get all the cans, or to get them all very, very slow.
You switch back and forth and the winner of each round is determined by either who gets the most cans, or if it's a tie, whichever team got them all the quickest.

Ahh, the game mode that sucked me in and took my life from me.  Scavenge is really fun.  But be warned, a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s chill in this gamemode.  Brush yo' shoulder off.

Mutations
Whenever.
Fun gamemodes that you can and should play with your friends.  You can play them alone too, though.  I haven't played them all so I don't think I can accurately portray them, but they are fun.

Realism & Realism Versus
Realism is campaign but on crack.  You can't see each other through walls anymore, you're basically relying on each other to stick together.  Other aspects of the gameplay are hard too, like zombies taking more damage.  Great team building gamemode.

Realism Versus is basically versus with realism thrown in it ^ (read above)

reviewText:
Difficulty: Just Right
The Bottom Line: Great Multiplayer/Superb
Score: 9.0

While L4D2 improves upon the original in many meaningful ways, it fails to recapture the same magic.
While I was never one of those people who threw their arms in protest when L4D2  was announced, I was nonetheless a bit skeptical as to whether or not a fully fledged sequel, After spending time with L4D2, I can with no uncertainty say that this game is indeed a true sequel, as opposed to a glorified expansion pack. The sequel not only provides a new setting (one with more character when compared to the original), new characters, new weapons and new enemies, but entirely new gameplay mechanics. It feels fresh and new and yet at the same time, comfortingly familiar.

L4D2 is an improvement over the original in almost every aspect. But it fails somewhat in one major aspect, it just doesn't feel as magical or expertly crafted as its predecessor.
voteText: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
While Left 4 Dead 2 had a rocky start, Valve greatly improved the quality of the game after release. In almost every way L4D2 replicates it's predecessor and surpasses it at the same time.

L4D2 unlike it's predecessor has maps that take place during the day. It features more special infected that require constant movement and cover. And it features melee weapons that add an entirely new dynamic to gameplay. All of these features are woven very well with the carried over elements from L4D1. The game still requires players stick together inorder to avoid being pounced by legions of undead and it keeps the frantic fast paced atmosphere. Alongside that, the game's versus mode adds a great deal of strategy to the gameplay. And lastly it's survival mode allows players to test their skills and provide a nice healthy amount of competition amongst each other.

I'd go as far as to say L4D2 now is one of Valve's best attempts at multiplayer games on the Source engine. Harder, Faster, Better and Stronger in almost every way.

reviewText:
I originally got this game because a friend convinced me to. I was hesitant because it was a zombie game and I didn't handle well in the Call of Duty: Nazi Zombies game. After I bought it, I noticed very quickly that this game makes friends FAST! It promotes teamwork between 4 players known as survivors, as they try to make it to the CEDA extraction point.

Specifically, this story follows Nick, Ellis, Coach, and Rochelle. Each character has a personality of their own, unlike Gordon Freeman or Chell from other Valve games.

Nick was a gambler, according to the commentary, he looted his white suit to survive in style. He often sounds stern, and serious about their situation. As in Dark Carnival he says in response to Coach and Ellis's excitement, Now we can die there as adults."

Ellis is a child at heart

reviewText: This game is an unbelievable zombie survival game with loads of different game modes to play. The gameplay is much more fun as a multiplayer allowing people to choose servers that they prefer. Admins can tweak game modes and rules to their spec to make the game more fun or challenging. The game has loads of different weapons to choose from and also has the original campaigns from L4D1. In versus mode you can play as a survivor or the undead. The undead have different classes such as smokers tongue ability to hold the victim, spitters venom that damages the survivors and hunters pounce which pins down the survivor. Overall a brilliant fps game with plenty of replay value. 92%

reviewText:
I gave this game several tries, but I just can't recommend this game. It's very difficult to finish a Versus match without having the cancerous community kick you. This is the perfect example of a great game ruined by its community- I have never seen the kick option be so abused in a game before.

If you have a group of friends with you, then you should be set. Playing by yourself is another thing. You will be kicked constantly- often for no reason at all. I actually found myself kicked for healing one teammate over the other(who were both in the same shape).

Save your money and time- this game's horrid community will anger you if you decide to play alone, as it did for me. This is a game that I only recommend playing with friends. You'll find yourself lucky to find a server that isn't full of elitist morons.

I don't recommend this game is because of my personal preferences.
Overall, this game is fun when played online but the one thing missing about it is the feature to actually mute other players.

reviewText:
This truly is one of the better zombie games i have played on the PC. What i like so much about valve games is the amount of time the valve developers spend on perfecting all the tiny details that shape the universe from their games which makes left 4 dead 2 a little special.

But as nice as this game is i have a few things that worry me. Even though the game itself is a jewel worth playing in more than one way, in the various lobbies i created i keep running into people who join the team but only care for themir own needs. They don themselves as experts or pros or even both sometimes but in reality all that ever happens is that these players start rushing the maps while other players nomatter how often they have played this game don't get a proper oppertunity to get a taste of the athmosphere and as a result get isolated from the rest.

In some cases you even get an immature big fat mouth from them when things don't go their way. It's a problem i have noticed eversince i started playing this game. Needless to say in time my preferance for short plays in spare time went over from co-op to using the standard bots which i really regret but is a problem i often hear from the gamers i know.

With that in mind we can all jump high or low about it but it is the way it is. The best i can recommend is to play this game with good friends because let's be honest that's what you have friends for. Especially with left 4 dead 2. Wouldn't it be a big waste to let an awesome game like this be overshadowed by a bunch of underage anons who never learned what gaming is all about?

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead 2 is a game where a group of four survivors - Miku Hatsune, Ostrava of Boletaria, Rainbow Dash, and Yui Hirasawa - go about trying to find a way to get home. During their travels, they find that they have angered the Queen of Hearts by shooting too many of her Card Guards and now must fight the Guard Armor From Kingdom Hearts. After trumping the armored beast, the fumbling foursome come upon a cashe of mythical weapons, ones that fire searing hot lasers from the ends. Kicking the door down, they proceed to the final battle where Dont Lose Your Way starts to play in the backround...

Wait, no, that's not right...
No, no, that IS right...

reviewText:
Many people love L4D2, following the incredible success of L4D.
Personally, I think this game is a heap of ♥♥♥♥ - and I love just about every other Valve game.
Technically and graphically, it is better than L4D, and unfortunately, that's the only part it is better. In everything else, it stinks.

Gone is the atmosphere, the friendly rivalry between Louis and Francis, the grainy 70's film effect (seriously, wtf were you thinking), dark brooding cityscapes, and the witty repartee between all four members.
Instead, you get four unlikeable characters that spend more time whining and ♥♥♥♥♥ing at each other, bright sunny days in New Orleans, and near constant waves of zombies.
In fact, that is the main thing that irks me about the sequel. In the first one, if you had a strong member of the team, there was a fair chance they could pull the the rest of the team through, which made for some hectic, but fun, gameplay.
In L4D2, there is no chance of that. The waves are too relentless and the specials spawn far too frequently, so if the team is a little disorganised, you're ♥♥♥♥ed with a capital F.
Once the game decides it is going to target you, that's it until you either run of medkits or the team gets tired of trying to protect you. More often that not, you're spawning back at the safehouse, because one player got boomed, jockeyed and then incapped in the spitter goo.
Cue ragequitting from less invested members of the team. The fun factor just shines through at that point (/sarcasm)

I've tried hard to like this game, really I have.
God knows I've put enough hours into it, but I just can't bring myself to like it in any way shape or form. In fact, I've gone from trying to like it to hating it, and have completely removed it off my PC. If I could delete it from my Steam library, I would.

L4D may have had it's flaws, but it certainly had atmosphere and characters you could warm to, and my final verdict is that L4D2 does not hold a candle to it.
To sum it up - in the first game, you felt like you were all fighting against hordes of zombies.
In the second one, it feels like you are fighting everything in the game - zombies, weather, terrain - some maps are just a slow grindingly weary slog from start to finish.

It's cheap enough to pick up for a bit of fun, and you might like it, but I seriously can't recommend it when the preceding game was far FAR superior in gameplay.

reviewText:
Amazing game. A true example of innovation done right in gaming.

-Graphics: crisp, clean textues and environments. 720p and up.

-Frame Rate: 60fps and up.

-Sound: Audio is breathtaking, clear, and optimized.

-Gameplay: Incredible. A simple system that's easy for first time players to learn, yet complex to offer late game masters something to calculate with. Balanced enemies, spawn rates, weapons, movements, HP system, and ammo capacity. Can be as challenging, easy, or unforgiving as you want. Well tailored to any and all players.

-Level design: Environments are diverse and uniquely pathed to offer a different feel and strategy per level. Spawns and item placements are mostly randomized, yet still manages to make use of every corner of the maps. Direction and pace of play is linear, but never gets old or burdensome.

-Multiplayer: Fast connections, great server support, one button in game press to check your signal strength. Local, dedicated, and undedicated server support.

-Customization: Near everything can be modded to suit anything you can think up. Textures, sounds, maps, Ai, objectives, text.

reviewText: Even though it's an old teamwork-oriented game, it still is so much fun to play on and has so many things to do; never gets boring if you have 2-3 friends to play together in versus games. Also, the custom campaigns from the workshop add a boost of entertaining and the scavenge on the rooftop from No Mercy map is very awesome. The plot is simple because all you need to do is to go from a safe house to another killing everything which is in your way. I spent on over 2k hours on and the price is worth it, that's why i highly suggest everyone who's interested in good content should try this.\nIt has its ups and downs. You can basically meet all sorts of people in the community, nicer or less nicer, from where you can choose to play further. This is why it's very competitive. From time to time, you can experience minor bugs but they don't downgrade the experience.\nIn conclusion, I give this game 10/10, one of the best old games out there!

reviewText:
Product received for free

MINIMALISTIC REVIEW

Pros:
- Fast-paced gameplay
- Variety of weapons, attachments and bullet customization (eg; fire bullets, frag bullets, etc.).
- UI and HUD is simple and understandable.
- Story is well-organized and well-relayed (if the players do put attention on the story)
- Melee weapons are introduced.
- L4D game is combined to this game with a bonus top-rated community map featured on the game.
- Variety of zombies and also the special common infected (eg; riot zombie, hazmat zombie).
- Epic and challenging map and level designs.
- Tutorials are user-friendly.
- Features a band that KINDA existed (Midnight Riders!!!! WHOOO!!)
- Music blends perfectly on the environment.
- New systems have been added to the game that were not available on L4D (eg; witch's critical hit, etc.)
- Characters are great and accomodated to the post-apocalyptic scenario.
- No DLCs. Just pure fun.
- Mods are welcomed (have your own style of the apocalypse).
- YOU CAN BE THE INFECTED! Now that is fun.
- Can be played with potato PCs.

Cons:
- Item physics are wobbling and act like light plastic (most especially the gas cans).
- AI Survivors were designed to just shoot and pick up items (ammunitions to be specific). They are not designed to interact with certain objects given by the map.
- Some weapons that are available at the game files are not accessible in the game (eg; AWP).

RATING: 9/10 would shoot alarmed cars again.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead 2 is a fast pace first person shooter. Swarm full of zombies and a variety of 8 special infected to kill or play with. Each survivor has their own personality & lingo to them that will keep you entertained throughout the game when taking down the zombies. I see this title an inspiration to games that shows its not all about the graphics but the potiental that many cant conflict on. When i mean by the potiental is the gameplay its self, its always going to be a challenge to master, no matter how long you play it. It has many features to offer from weapons, to game modes for certain players with different taste E.g (Campaign/Realism/VS/Survival/Mutation)

I have all do respect to the co-devlopers Valve for bringing out as much features for the Left 4 Dead community such as: L4D1 Campaigns, new DLC such as the Passing, Sacrfice & Cold stream for free. Workshop amendments for users that would like to create and download mods from authors content. Thats just to show that its not all about the money in the gaming industry but the respect valve has for the gamers. So I thank you valve for what you have offered.

I would reccomend this game to the players that enjoy frantic and non-stop action shooters. After reading this review i hope you make the right decision on purchasing the game.

reviewText: Once again Valve set the standard for game development! L4D2 is, on the surface, a simple game based upon easy to understand principles and mechanics... however it is a game of outstanding depth and complexity that takes many 1000s of hours play to master. Recomendations for new players. 1) Learn the game in easy/normal coop mode before moving on to higher levels and competitive modes. 2) Try to make friends with players who are of a similar level as yourself, there is no matchmaking in L4D2 but you will have a far more enjoyable time playing with players like yourself. 3) L4D2 is a TEAM game, if you join a random game your actions could very dramatically effect the progression of the game for the other players, a game that may have been going on for a long time before your arrival. Show respect for other players, if you just want to mess about please don't ruin other peoples games at the same time, this is not TF2 or CS casual where you can jump in and out of games without having any effect on other people playing the game. If you are a solo gamer, who always likes doing their own thing, who plays alone and doenst want to think about or worry about other players, then L4D2 is NOT RECOMMENDED FOR YOU!

reviewText:
If you don't have this game already, and like First Person Shooters... get it. It's sometimes on sale for only a few dollars, and on occasion has even been free for a weekend or Christmas.

The best co-op game I've ever played, hands down. I spent nearly a thousand hours playing campaign mode before even dipping a toe into Versus or Scavenge game modes. These (competitive) multiplayer modes are very fun also, but be aware that you will be expected to have mastered the learning curve BEFORE jumping into these - your teammates will expect you to know the game already, and there's virtually no on-the-job training, so to speak. ;)

L4D2 includes pretty much all the content of L4D1, and a bunch more besides - 4 new survivors, 3 new Special Infected, 5 new campaigns, new uncommon infected" specific to these new campaigns
date: and new player-usable items in every category. Plus an add-on workshop to customize your game when it finally starts feeling stale. In terms of play hours per dollar spent
recommended: no other game I have EVER played comes close.\n\nSo if you're wondering whether to get this game? Get it
hoursPlayed: especially if you can get it on sale. Even if you only play it a bit and put it aside for other things
voteText: you'll probably be glad you have it in your library to play with friends occasionally."
